title: Labour suspend MP Stephen Hepburn over sexual harassment allegation
text:

Jarrow MP Stephen Hepburn has been suspended from the Labour party while a complaint of sexual harassment against him is investigated.

The accusations against Mr Hepburn are understood to surround claims of inappropriate behaviour towards a woman in 2005.

Mr Hepburn told the BBC that he "completely refutes" the allegation.

He added that he "welcomes the investigation so that the matter can be put to rest".

The decision to suspend the MP was taken by a panel consisting of members of Labour's ruling body, the National Executive Committee, and following advice from an independent barrister

The case will now be referred to the party's disciplinary panel, the National Constitutional Committee.

The NCC has the power to expel people from the party or impose time-limited suspensions.

According to HuffPost UK , which reported the initial allegations, a complaint about the MP was first lodged two years ago but dropped.

It was reportedly reopened after another MP submitted evidence about the alleged incident.

A Labour Party spokesperson confirmed the suspension and told the Mirror: “The Labour Party takes all complaints of sexual harassment extremely seriously, which are fully investigated and any appropriate disciplinary action taken in line with the Party’s rules and procedures.

“We are determined to challenge and overturn sexual harassment and misogyny within politics and across society as a whole.

"We cannot comment on individual complaints."
